page.title: 03ECOLOGY OF LINKENHOLT
page.content: Linkenholt is a typical chalk downland village; the soil being loam and clay on chalk. Arable crops grown are wheat and barley. Sheep are kept but no other livestock. Pheasants are reared for shooting, the shoots organised by a syndicate that pays the estate. One keeper is employed. Deer are to be seen in the woods near the village. A Barn Owl nested near farm buildings this year. Bats live in the church and woodpeckers are often to be seen on the church roof, and have caused damage to the wooden tiles on the bell turret in the past. There are many footpaths and green lanes crossing the land. The wet weather in the summer in 1985 produced a wet and expensive harvest.
